BMI Formula

Body Mass Index (BMI) is a simple formula used to calculate whether a person has a healthy weight for their height.
Formula: BMI = Weight in kilograms / (Height in meters)^2

BMI FAQs

  1. How accurate is BMI?
    ► BMI is a general indicator and may not be accurate for athletes.
  2. What is a normal BMI range?
    ► The normal BMI range is between 18.5 and 24.9.

How to Improve BMI

1. Balanced Diet

  • Whole grains: Choose oats, brown rice.
  • Protein: Lean meats, beans for muscle.
  • Healthy fats: Avocado, nuts, olive oil.

2. Regular Exercise

  • Cardio: Walk, run, or cycle daily.
  • Strength: Build muscle to boost metabolism.

3. Lifestyle Habits

  • Hydrate: Drink water to aid digestion.
  • Sleep: 7-8 hours nightly to regulate hunger.

BMI Health Risks

Underweight (BMI < 18.5)

  • Nutrient deficiencies
  • Weakened immune system
  • Osteoporosis risk
  • Fertility issues

Overweight (BMI 25-29.9) and Obesity (BMI ≥ 30)

  • Heart disease
  • Type 2 diabetes
  • High blood pressure
  • Joint problems

Side Effects of Abnormal BMI

Low BMI Effects:

  • Reduced energy levels
  • Poor concentration
  • Delayed wound healing
  • Hormonal imbalances

High BMI Effects:

  • Sleep apnea
  • Respiratory problems
  • Increased cancer risk
  • Mental health issues

History of BMI

The Body Mass Index (BMI) was developed by Belgian mathematician Adolphe Quetelet in the 1830s. Originally called the Quetelet Index, it became widely adopted as a health measure in the 1970s.

Key Developments:

  • 1830s: Initial development by Quetelet
  • 1972: Renamed to Body Mass Index
  • 1985: WHO adopts BMI standards
  • Present: Global standard for weight assessment
